I reached out here, I reached out to my sponsor, I reached out to my home group and my family. I made a very big deal out of this appointment, which I discovered was simply my addiction rearing its head... Well, I didn't take one. I took the ibuprofen, and I relaxed and I got through the worst of it so far.

I've dealt with it with ice and NSAIDs, chiropractic care, acupuncture and massage... I figured with all this clean time, I'd be safe to risk the need for surgery. ...My husband has the pills stashed, there were only 16 5mg Percocet given to me and I've only taken 6, total. (2 at a time) Never took them during the day, never got loaded at that dose and yet I still feel disappointed in myself... My sponsor has been unavailable for the last couple of days, so I haven't shared with her yet, but I know that she will not consider this a relapse since I took them less than prescribed and do not have access to them. ...That phenomenon of craving is so fucking real, and there has never been any doubt that I'm a true-blue addict regarding these pills.

I had powered through, acupuncture, massage, physical therapy and every NSAID possible. The pain was destroying my will to live. Asked for Percs because I don't like percs. Made a plan with my sponsor, had my husband hold the pills and only took them at night. ... What am I supposed to do? I know that I am a fucking jackass when it comes to this shit, but it isn't until the evening when I realize I can't live this way.

The fact that time is so universally important in recovery can be beyond frustrating and discouraging, because you can't buy it (as we are used to doing with things we want and/or need), and you can't do anything else except to wait in order to have it. Early in recovery the thoughts of using are so non-stop that it feels as if this is never going to change. But I was not listening to the advice of my peers which was, in essence, that if you can give yourself enough clean time, you will arrive at a place that is remarkably different than the one you are in right now in your head.

I remember when I was using that if I was honest with myself, the answer was always that I wanted to change things and wanted to stop- but the next thought would be that I needed to make a plan first, and certainly couldn’t start right then, because I wanted to do it ‘right’. And if not that, then it would be some other complete bullshit nonsense excuse that my brain would trick me into believing, thus delaying doing what I knew deep down that I really wanted to do.

Myself as well as the large majority of opiate users I have met along my journey through recovery all have almost the same story. Got injured in some way, got prescribed Vicodin, Percocet, Oxys, even fucking Fentanyl in some cases- and then, after unknowingly becoming physically dependent on the medication (which the doctors often failed to warn about), the doc suddenly ends the script. And as I’m sure you all know how the story continues, I’ll just skip to the part where you are in desperate need of help and recovery.
This probably applies more to people on maintenance, as I would imagine if you get the flu while actively using, that’s most likely just a reason to use more to make it ‘better’.

I was in recovery, and actually a year or so into it at that point... Never once did I think that I would ever think about dope (and it’s companions) without romanticizing. But I was wrong. I just want to write this so that those who are in the state and/or timeframe that I was in at this point two years ago to know that it gets so, so much better... Don’t let this shit define you. Instead, let it be something that maybe did define you for a little bit, or however long, but now YOU define IT as a bad time in your life- but a time in which you realized what was happening- and during which you took back control.
